chunks.en: Just saw news about Mercedes layoffs, N+9?!
Compared to the various shady practices in China, this is really disheartening.
Truly treating employees as people instead of livestock. ğŸ‘
@han1988 #16 What does that have to do with ordinary people? Ordinary people only care about which companies are unwilling to give even a penny, and which companies give enough.

This is the difference between foreign and Chinese companies. Foreign companies consider your family and future when hiring you. If they really can't operate and have to lay off employees, they also consider your family and job search situation. What do companies in our country treat employees as? As tools. They spend a lot of money to poach you when they urgently need you, and when they want to lay you off, they think about laying you off without spending money or spending as little money as possible. They don't understand that many people's jobs support a family, and being laid off almost means mortgage default and family destruction. They don't even want to pay this n+1 buffer compensation.
Regarding this kind of behavior, we should always be vigilant of ____, severely crack down on _____, improve ______, so that ______, and ultimately _______.

chunks.en: @sagaxu Oh, are you talking about net profit margin again? What's so strange about a heavy asset car manufacturer having a net profit margin of less than 10%? But can't you see the difference between actual profit and net profit? Do you need someone to teach you the difference between 10% of 100 and 10% of 100 million? As for per capita, front-line workers at BYD are not even considered people, so don't talk about per capita. The low-price, involution route was their own choice, and the poor quality was their own making, so they can't blame others. As for over 90% of private enterprises, you better add some qualifiers. Large-scale, heavy asset industries don't primarily look at net profit margin. What about setting up factories in Europe and the United States? Don't even think about it. Not to mention human resources issues, these garbage companies like BYD have a bunch of problems with their assembly line factories, so it's not even about human resources issues.
@winglight2016 Many domestic companies that have become world leaders can't even do this.
@han1988 So, if it's according to N+1 or 2N, does that comply with Chinese law?
Decent

This shows that Mercedes has high profits and high brand premium. What they give to employees is just a drop in the bucket, but at least they still treat employees as people and are decent. This is much better than those domestic companies that exploit everything, which is why everyone is scrambling to go to foreign companies.

@zuosiruan You're just stupid. Mercedes wants to remit profits from China back to China and can't risk being strangled by labor disputes. A few years ago, Twitter suddenly laid off half of its employees, thousands of people. Musk said I've already done better than the law requires. The law requires two months' notice, but I'm simply not letting them work starting tomorrow, and I'm giving them three months' severance pay. Of course, some large internet companies like Facebook feel that employees have followed them for many years and have worked hard, so they give 4 months of compensation when laying off employees.
@nickyadance23 Don't even think about it. Others calculate based on average monthly salary, which is much better than garbage companies like BYD and Huawei.
@han1988 Judging by actions, not intentions, that's what all Chinese people do, are you saying you're the only smart and capable one?

@crocoBaby Which well-known foreign company that can come to China to open a company isn't a rarity? Mercedes had trillion-yuan revenue last year, with a profit margin about twice the industry average and a net profit of 40,000 per car. The highest of its Chinese counterparts is less than 1/3 of that. BYD has 5 times the number of employees as Mercedes, but only half the profit. Different positions in the food chain, money can't come from thin air.
This is why you keep shouting about supporting domestic products, supporting your **,

Seems like: N + 9 + 2 months of salary + ten years of year-end bonus.
@shadowyue #12 Common prosperity, common prosperity.

Foreign companies are also divided into different levels. Look at the Big Four, aren't they foreign companies? There's still a lot of overtime and layoffs, and the compensation is just the standard n+1. Generally speaking, the lower the localization of a foreign company, the better the treatment. Also, Europe > America > Japan/Korea > Hong Kong/Taiwan.
